Al-Ḥallāj is considered the first Islamic thinker to break with conventional theology and defend Iblīs’s rebellion against God. In his al-Ṭawāsīn he contends that Iblīs could not reconcile bowing to Adam with being a servant to the eternal divine decree. Unable to bring himself to overstep (as he saw it) the bounds of God’s infinite wisdom, power and knowledge, he had no choice but to refuse the command to bow to Adam. He could read his fate in a clear record ( kitāb mubīn ) and he knew what would become of him, but he saw his free-will and choice as coming from God, not from himself. Therefore, he said: ‘All choice, including mine, belongs to You. It is You who chose for me. If there is anything that prevents me from bowing to him, it is You… and if You had truly willed that I bow to him, I would have obeyed! (al-Ḥallāj, al-Ṭawāsīn , 189–190).

In fact, al-Ḥallāj–to the outrage of many–considered Iblīs to be the paragon of monotheism and a true and devoted lover who saw and knew nothing besides his Beloved. Accordingly, he is superior to and more knowledgeable than all; and, although he has been driven away from the divine presence, he still holds fast to this love. Iblīs’s service is still purer, and his remembrance of God brighter, because previously he had served his beloved and deity for himself, whereas now he serves God only for God. Iblīs even considers his arrogance and pride to be justified, saying: ‘If I spent but a moment with Him, I would be justified in my pride and arrogance. But I have been in God’s presence since eternity!’ Iblīs was warned of Hellfire, but he would not relent. He was told: ‘Prostrate!’ but said: ‘To no other.’ He was told: ‘Upon you shall be My curse until the Day of Resurrection’, but said again: ‘For no other.’ Then he said ‘Even if You punish me for all eternity, I will prostrate to no one but God’ (see al-Ḥallāj, al-Ṭawāsīn , 190–192; ‘Tafsīr’, 109–110; q.v. 2/601–602; Nicholson, The Idea , 42–45).

Although al-Ḥallāj praised Iblīs’s nobility, chivalry and monotheism, he condemned him for refusing to obey a divine command. As has already been mentioned, al-Ḥallāj drew an explicit comparison between Iblīs and the Prophet Muḥammad in the chapter Azal wa al-iltibās in his Ṭawāsīn . According to Rūzbihān Baqlī, Iblīs was the leader of the angels as the Prophet is the leader of humanity. ‘Just as the Prophet is the keeper of God’s pre-eternal grace ( lu ṭ fiyya azaliyya ), Iblīs is the keeper of His everlasting power ( qahriyya abadiyya ). The Prophet was created from the lights of kindness, while Iblīs was created from the flame of power. That which is subtle ( laṭīf ) is the source of kindnesses ( luṭfiyyāt ), while that which is turbid ( kathīf  ) is the source of torments ( qahriyyāt )…He misguides whom He wills and He guides whom He wills’ ( Sharḥ , 508–510).

Al-Ḥallāj believed love to be one of the attributes of the divine Essence, and likened it to a flame. It is the light of the first flame, burning eternally, coloured with every conceivable colour and endowed with every conceivable attribute. God’s Essence flares within itself, and His attributes glow within themselves. Its source is He-ness ( huwiyya ) and it is free from Self-ness ( inniyya ); it is manifestly hidden, its essence is the reality of existence, and its attributes reflect complete perfection (al-Ḥallāj, ‘al-Dīwān’, 288; see also al-Daylamī, ʿAṭf , 90–91; ʿAbbās, 244). Al-Ḥallāj believed love to be an extreme longing in a person’s heart, caused by the majesty and beauty ( jalāl wa jamāl ) of God overwhelming them, intensified by witnessing the existence of the Beloved, until nothing except the Beloved remained. If this is according to God’s will ( mashiyya ), then it is for Him, from Him, with Him, to Him, by Him, in Him, upon Him, Him alone, and Him. Therefore, it is He who longs for those who seek Him (al-Ḥallāj, ‘Tafsīr’, 112; al-Daylamī, ʿAṭf , 131).
AL-ḤALLĀJ AS VIEWED BY SUFIS

The complex nature of al-Ḥallāj’s personality and his eccentric—and sometimes contradictory—behaviour not only provoked the anger of non-Sufis but also gave rise to concerns amongst many leading gnostics of his day. According to al-Hujwīrī (q.v., d. late 5th/11th century), only a handful of these Sufi masters, including Abū al-ʿAbbās b. ʿAṭāʾ Adamī (d. 309/921), Abū al-Qāsim Naṣrābādī (q.v.) (d. 367/977), and Ibn Khafīf of Shīrāz (d. 371/981), took a wholly positive view of al-Ḥallāj and were prepared to defend him openly.

Of these, Ibn ʿAṭāʾ Adamī lost his life defending al-Ḥallāj (Ibn Kathīr, 11/144; al-Baghdādī, 248–250; al-Khaṭīb, 8/112; ʿAṭṭār, Tadhkira , 583; see also Jāmī, Nafaḥāt , 143–144; see also Nicholson, ‘Ḥallāj’, 481); Naṣrābādī was an important promoter of al-Ḥallāj’s teachings and doctrines in Khurāsān. He also made copies of his works, which may explain why he preached and taught in secret (al-Hujwīrī, 229). After meeting al-Ḥallāj in prison, Ibn Khafīf, described him as a celestial scholar with a pleasant countenance, an awe-inspiring presence, and steadfast character: ‘If what I saw from him was not monotheism ( tawḥīd ), then who in this world is a monotheist?’ (see al-Daylamī, Sīra , 93–97, 100–101; al-Sulamī, Ṭabaqāt , 308, 485; Ibn Bākūya, 32–33, 38; Anṣārī, Ṭabaqāt , 380; Jāmī, Nafaḥāt , 153).

Other Sufis, such as al-Junayd al-Baghdādī (d. 297/910), Abū Bakr al-Shiblī (d. 334/945), Abū Muḥammad Aḥmad al-Jurayrī (d. 311/924), ʿAlī b. Ibrāhīm al-Ḥuṣrī (q.v., d. 371/982), ʿAbd al-Karīm al-Qushayrī (d. 521/1127) and even Kh w ājah ʿAbd Allāh al-Anṣārī Harawī (q.v., d. 481/1089) chose to remain silent and withhold judgement on his case (al-Hujwīrī, 229–230; cf. Massignon, Akhbār , 338). Anṣārī is reported to have said that he knew al-Ḥallāj’s utterances only incompletely and therefore, preferred to refrain from judging him ( Ṭabaqāt , 380, see also 383; ‘Ilāhī-nāmah’, 2/662).

However there were several Sufis, including ʿAmr b. ʿUthmān al-Makkī, Abū Yaʿqūb al-Nahrjūrī, Abū Yaʿqūb al-Aqṭaʿ, and ʿAlī b. Sahl al-Iṣfahānī, who publicly condemned al-Ḥallāj, and some, such as Ibrāhīm b. Shaybān and Abū Bakr al-Ṣūlī, who accused him of believing in incarnation and unification [with God] (q.v. ḥulūl wa ittiḥād ), as well as being a heretic, a Qarmaṭī, and a trickster (see Massignon, Akhbār , 338; Ibn al-Nadīm, 269–270; al-Khaṭīb, 8/112, 118–121, 129; al-Hujwīrī, 229–230; Ibn al-Jawzī, al-Muntaẓam , 13/202–203; ʿAṭṭār, Tadhkira , 584–585; Ibn al-Athīr, 8/126–127; Ibn Khallikān, 2/140–141; al-Dhahabī, Siyar , 14/314, 317–318; Ibn Kathīr, 11/144, 149; Jāmī, Nafaḥāt , 153). Some of his critics devoted portions of their own works to exposing what they considered to be his trickery. According to ʿAbd al-Qāhir al-Baghdādī (p. 247), these included Qāḍī Abū Bakr Muḥammad b. Ṭayyib al-Ashʿarī whose work about the inability of the Muʿtazila to verify the evidence of prophethood ascribed a variety of magic tricks and sleights of hand to al-Ḥallāj (for other cases, see al-Khaṭīb, 8/122–127; Ibn Kathīr, 11/144 et passim).
LATER VIEWS ON AL-ḤALLĀJ

Despite the different ways in which he was perceived and received during his own lifetime, over the succeeding centuries many great Sufis extolled his sanctity and considered him as one of the true lovers of God. These included Abū Naṣr al-Sarrāj (d. 378/988), Abū Saʿīd b. Abī al-Khayr (q.v., d. 440/1049), Abū al-Qāsim Kurragānī (q.v. d. ca. 469/1076), Abū al-ʿAbbās Aḥmad b. Muḥammad Shaqqānī, Abū ʿAlī al-Fārmadī (q.v. d. 477/1084), Abū Yaʿqūb Yūsuf al-Hamadānī (q.v. d. 535/1141), and Jalāl al-Dīn Rūmī (d. 672/1273) (al-Hujwīrī, 229–230; Muḥammad b. Munawwar, 1/72; ʿAṭṭār, Tadhkira , 583; Aflākī, 1/285; Jāmī, Nafaḥāt , 153). He was nevertheless an ambivalent figure. In his Persian treatise Kashf al-maḥjūb , ʿAlī Hujwīrī (q.v.) has some praise for al-Ḥallāj; but he also devotes a section of chapter 14 of that work, concerning schools of Sufism and their tenets, to the school of his ostensible followers (Ḥallājiyān), decrying and classifying them among the invalid ones to be avoided. According to al-Yāfiʿī (2/253), mystics such as Abū Ḥāmid al-Ghazālī, ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī and Shihāb al-Dīn Suhrawardī sought to validate and al-Ḥallāj’s spiritual states. At the same time, such Sufi masters upheld the opinion that if taken literally, his utterances contravene the letter of the law (in Islam, such questions fall within the scope of sacred law). In any case, to have done otherwise could well have led to their own orthodoxy being impugned. Not long after them, by contrast, the famous Persian mystic Rūzbihān Baqlī of Shiraz (d. 605/1209) composed profound commentaries on the shatḥiyyāt of al-Ḥallāj and other Sufis, in both Arabic and Persian versions, exalting their author as one of the greatest of saints and gnostics.

Among the classical Persian poets, it is Farīd al-Dīn ‘Aṭṭār who is foremost in acclaiming Ḥusayn b. Manṣūr al-Ḥallāj as one of the greatest Sufis. Apart from the allusions to him in his poems– mathnawī s as well as ghazals–there is also the entry on al-Ḥallāj which constitutes a climactic passage in his biographical compilation of saints, Tadhkirat al-awliyā . Besides describing in vivid detail the physical torment which the execution (or martyrdom) of al-Ḥallāj involved, ‘Aṭṭār describes al-Junayd as having taken of his Sufi garb and donned that of a jurist before pronouncing him guilty according to sacred law. In reality, however, al-Junayd died ten years before al-Ḥallāj did. For ‘Aṭṭār, as for a number of later Persian poets of the same persuasion, al-Ḥallāj is the very paragon of self-sacrifice for the love of God. In his ghazals and in the Mathnawī , Jalāl al-Dīn quotes some phrases from his verses.

Admiration of ‘Manṣūr-i Ḥallāj’, as he is commonly referred to by such authors (‘Manṣūr meaning ‘granted victory’) as a martyr to divine love is often coupled with an acknowledgement that in saying ‘I am the Truth (or ‘I am God’), he was at fault in speaking openly of a spiritual secret that should never be publicly divulged because of the danger of its being misunderstood by the uninitiated. Thus, the renowned Persian mystical lyric poet Shams al-Dīn Ḥāfiẓ Shīrāzī (q.v.) states in one of his ghazals: ‘That great one by whom the gallows were ennobled, / His fault was this: that he divulged secrets.’

In the Arab world, in modern times, the figure of al-Ḥallāj has appeared in literary works, and even in the visual arts, as a symbol of fearless individualism and defiance of political authorities (Ernst, 33–34).
